G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a Probate and Family Court may modify a judgment concerning custody when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Sarah Johnson ("Plaintiff"), pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6, and Rule 15 of the Massachusetts Rules of Domestic Relations Procedure, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing judgment of custody entered on October 15, 2021, on the grounds that there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances adversely affecting the best interests of the minor child, Ethan Johnson (age 10).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The "best interests of the child" standard is paramount and guides all custody determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that the words “upon cause shown” in the removal statute mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and that this is the “central question” in the case. It further explains that although the custodial parent’s and noncustodial parent’s interests are considered, “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.” Thus, the opinion directly affirms that the best-interests standard is paramount and guiding in custody-related determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”}

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.proposition: A material change exists where the circumstances upon which the earlier judgment was based no longer reflect the present reality or threaten the child’s welfare.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.support_reasoning: The opinion recites the general standard that a party must show a “material change of circumstances” to modify alimony or child support, but it does not define material change in terms of whether earlier circumstances no longer reflect present reality or threaten the child’s welfare. Instead, the court focuses on the obligor’s income, earning capacity, and assets, ultimately holding no material change occurred. The language in this case does not articulate or adopt the specific formulation of material change stated in the proposition, nor does it tie material change to a threat to the child’s welfare.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion. … A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered… However … such a decrease does not alone compel a modification.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599 (1.proposition: The Court has a continuing duty to safeguard a child’s welfare where new conditions render the prior order inconsistent with the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child and remands for further findings. It does not, however, articulate a general principle that the court has a *continuing* duty to safeguard a child’s welfare when new conditions arise or that changed circumstances render a prior order inconsistent with the child’s best interests. The brief mention that three years have passed and the judge may wish to re‑interview the child is discretionary and does not amount to a stated continuing-duty doctrine.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.… As almost three years have gone by since the Probate Court issued its judgment and Vaughn is now almost fourteen years of age, it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference and for the judge to evaluate the success of the stipulated custody arrangement the parties have been living under in the interim.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (200.proposition: Evidence of parental substance abuse and failure to provide a stable environment has repeatedly been found sufficient to warrant modification.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (200.support_reasoning: The case is a nonmarital custody allocation dispute and an interpretation of the G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) ‘best interests’ standard, not a modification proceeding. The opinion does not discuss parental substance abuse, instability, or standards for modifying an existing custody order based on such evidence; instead it affirms an original custody judgment between two fit parents. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that evidence of parental substance abuse and failure to provide a stable environment is sufficient to warrant modification.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (200.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’ … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 888.proposition: Evidence of parental substance abuse and failure to provide a stable environment has repeatedly been found sufficient to warrant modification.
Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 888.support_reasoning: The case concerns termination of parental rights and dispensing with consent to adoption based on parental unfitness, not a modification of an existing custody or adoption order. While the opinion notes drug use and an itinerant, unstable lifestyle as factors supporting a finding of unfitness, it does not discuss standards for or holdings about modification proceedings. Thus it cannot be accurately cited for the specific proposition that such evidence is sufficient to warrant modification.
Adoption of Quentin, 424 Mass. 882, 888.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that there was adequate evidence to support the findings that: the parents maintained an unsafe and unsanitary home and failed to take steps to correct these conditions; the parents lived an itinerant lifestyle which was harmful to the children; they neglected the emotional well-being of the children; the father never displayed a long-term commitment to stay with the family; the father used the public assistance funds to purchase drugs; the mother lacked the ability to protect the children from the father’s harmful conduct… Taken together, these facts provide clear and convincing evidence that both parents were unfit.”

Custody of Victoria, 473 Mass. 64, 72 (2.proposition: The Court may impose conditions or limitations such as supervised visits when necessary to protect the child while maintaining parental contact.
Custody of Victoria, 473 Mass. 64, 72 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused entirely on whether Massachusetts courts have jurisdiction under G.L. c. 209B over the custody of an unaccompanied refugee minor. It analyzes home state, default, emergency, and appropriate forum jurisdiction, but does not discuss remedies, visitation, or the imposition of conditions such as supervised visits to protect a child while maintaining parental contact. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about imposing supervised visitation or similar limitations.
Custody of Victoria, 473 Mass. 64, 72 (2.relevant_excerpt: Viewed broadly, the Massachusetts act grants jurisdiction where Massachusetts is the child’s “home [S]tate,” but also allows a Massachusetts court to exercise jurisdiction when, in the Legislature’s judgment, it may be appropriate to do so in the best interests of the child even though the Commonwealth is not the child’s home State. We review each statutory basis for jurisdiction in turn.

Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795, 799 (.proposition: The Court may impose conditions or limitations such as supervised visits when necessary to protect the child while maintaining parental contact.
Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795, 799 (.support_reasoning: The opinion recounts that the Juvenile Court judge, after granting temporary custody to the department, ordered that visits with the mother be supervised and that the boyfriend have no contact, but the Supreme Judicial Court does not discuss or adopt any legal standard about imposing supervised visitation or other conditions to protect the child while maintaining parental contact. Its analysis focuses on standards of appellate review and the sufficiency of evidence of parental unfitness, not on the court’s authority to craft conditional visitation orders. Thus, the case describes such conditions factually but does not establish the cited proposition as a legal rule.
Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795, 799 (.relevant_excerpt: “After a full hearing, the judge granted temporary custody of Eleanor and Carol to the department, ordered that they be placed in foster care, required that their visits with their mother be supervised, and ordered Flanders to have no contact with either child.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The doctrine permitting modification applies equally to shared legal custody where communication breakdown or parental unfitness undermines the child’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses when joint (shared) custody is appropriate, emphasizing that it requires cooperative, communicative, and mutually respectful parents and that it is inappropriate where there is serious antagonism and disagreement. However, the case involves an original award of sole custody to the mother, not a post-judgment modification of an existing shared legal custody arrangement. The court does not frame its analysis in terms of a ‘doctrine permitting modification’ or address how that doctrine applies to shared custody when communication breaks down, so it does not support the specific modification-related proposition claimed.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “However, we agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … ‘[J]oint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions in a manner similar to the way married couples make decisions.’ … [J]oint custody is encouraged primarily as a voluntary alternative for relatively stable, amicable parents behaving in mature civilized fashion.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.proposition: The doctrine permitting modification applies equally to shared legal custody where communication breakdown or parental unfitness undermines the child’s welfare.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standard for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint legal and physical custody arrangement. It does not discuss modification of shared legal custody, nor does it address communication breakdown or parental unfitness as grounds for modifying legal custody. The case instead focuses on a best-interests removal analysis within an existing joint custody framework, so it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about modification doctrine and shared legal custody.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.relevant_excerpt: “True joint custody is divisible into two components: shared legal custody and shared physical custody… Shared legal custody carries ‘mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in major decisions regarding the child’s welfare….’ … Shared physical custody in particular carries with it substantial obligation for cooperation between the parents. … In this case, the mother wishes to remove the children from the Commonwealth… The mother has thus requested permission from the court to remove the children. General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… [removal] must be in the best interests of the child.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court’s discretion to modify is also supported by Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981), Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986), and Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988), all recognizing the primacy of child safety and the need for prompt modification when material risk arises.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Bouchard concerns the criteria for making an initial custody determination, emphasizing that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and that all relevant factors must be weighed. It does not discuss a court’s authority or discretion to modify an existing custody order, nor does it address prompt modification when a material risk to the child arises. Thus, while it recognizes the primacy of the child’s welfare, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modification authority and timing.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: The Court’s discretion to modify is also supported by Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981), Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986), and Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988), all recognizing the primacy of child safety and the need for prompt modification when material risk arises.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a court’s discretion to promptly modify custody orders when new material risks to child safety arise. Custody of Two Minors here is a review of an initial care-and-protection/permanent custody judgment, not a modification of an existing order, and it does not discuss standards or discretion for later modification. While it strongly affirms the primacy of child safety and preventive intervention, it does not address or support the specific point about prompt modification when risk arises.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he right of parents to be free from intrusion by the State in matters of child-rearing [, however,] is not absolute.’ … In custody proceedings, the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment assume an importance at least equal to the interest of the parents in a fair proceeding. … ‘[T]he State interest in protecting … children may properly be preventive as well as remedial.’ Courts need not wait until they are confronted with a maltreated child before deciding that care and protection are necessary.”

Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.raw_text: Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988)
Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.proposition: The Court’s discretion to modify is also supported by Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981), Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986), and Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988), all recognizing the primacy of child safety and the need for prompt modification when material risk arises.
Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize the central goal of determining whether a child is in need of care and protection, but it does not discuss or establish a principle about a court’s discretion to promptly modify existing orders when new material risk to the child arises. The only modification mentioned is in a footnote describing later procedural history under G.L. c. 119, § 26, not as a holding about the scope of judicial discretion or the primacy of prompt modification. Thus, the case only indirectly reflects concern for child safety and does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
Care and Protection of Benjamin, 403 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The object of a proceeding under G.L.c. 119, §§ 24-26, is to determine whether a child is in need of care and protection and, if so, to enter an appropriate order for the care and custody of the child. … We remand the case for further consideration in light of this opinion and developments since the original hearing was held.”
